snippet: Pope Benedict XVI’s decision  to resign sets up a struggle between conservatives, who advocate a smaller church of more fervent Catholics, and those who believe that the  church can extend its reach.
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI’s surprise announcement that he will resign on Feb 28 sets the stage for a succession battle that is likely to determine the future course of a church troubled by scandal and declining faith in its traditional strongholds around the world;  citing  advanced years and infirmity, Benedict is the first pope in six centuries to resign; decision sets up a struggle between conservatives, who advocate a smaller church of more fervent Catholics, and those who believe that the  church can extend its reach.

byline.original: By RACHEL DONADIO and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
byline.contributor: Nicholas Kulish contributed reporting from Berlin, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: Pope Benedict XVI’s decision  to resign sets up a struggle between conservatives, who advocate a smaller church of more fervent Catholics, and those who believe that the  church can extend its reach.

headline.seo: Pope Resigns, With Church at Crossroads
headline.main: Successor to Benedict Will Lead a Church at a Crossroads
headline.print_headline: Pope Resigns, With Church at Crossroads
